{{Infobox military person |name = J. Garesche Ord |birth_date = {{Birth date|1886|10|18}} |death_date = {{death date and age|1960|04|17|1886|10|18}} |birth_place = Fort Lewis, [[Durango, Colorado]] |death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]] |placeofburial = [[Arlington National Cemetery]] |image = James Garesche Ord.jpg |caption = Major General J. Garesche Ord, Chairman of the Joint Brazil–U.S. Defense Commission in World War II. |nickname = "Sunny"
"Garry" |allegiance = {{flag|United States|1912|23px}} |branch = {{army|United States|23px}} |serviceyears = 1909–1946 |rank = [[File:US-O8 insignia.svg|30px]] [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] |servicenumber = O-2608 |commands =[[12th Infantry Regiment (United States)|12th Infantry Regiment]]
[[57th Infantry Regiment (United States)|57th Infantry Regiment]]
[[28th Infantry Division (United States)|28th Infantry Division]]

[[World War II]] |awards = [[Legion of Merit]]

[[Order of Military Merit (Brazil)]] (Grand Officer) |relations = [[Edward Otho Cresap Ord, II|Edward Otho Cresap Ord II]] (Father)

James Thompson Ord (Uncle)
[[James Basevi Ord]] (Cousin)
[[Edward Ord|Edward Otho Cresap Ord]] (Grandfather) |laterwork = }} '''James Garesche Ord''' (October 18, 1886 – April 17, 1960) was a [[United States Army]] [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] who Commanded the [[28th Infantry Division (United States)|28th Infantry Division]] and was Chairman of the Joint Brazil–U.S. Defense Commission during [[World War II]]. ==Early life== J. Garesche Ord, nicknamed "Sunny" and "Garry," was born at [[Fort Lewis College#History|Fort Lewis]] near [[Durango, Colorado]] on April 18, 1886. He was the son of [[Major (United States)|Major]] [[Edward Otho Cresap Ord, II|Edward Otho Cresap Ord II]] (1858–1923) and Mary Frances (Norton) Ord.West Point Association of Graduates, [http://apps.westpointaog.org/Memorials/Article/4799/ Memorial article, James Garesche Ord], retrieved June 11, 2014 His grandfather was [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] [[Edward Ord|Edward Otho Cresap Ord]] (1818–1883), and his great-grandfather was [[First lieutenant#U.S. Army, U.S. Marine Corps and U.S. Air Force|First Lieutenant]] James Ord (1789–1872).George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9Y-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1436 ''Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy''], Volume 6, Part 2, 1920, page 1436 His uncle, [[Jules Garesche Ord|Jules Garesche "Garry" Ord]] (1866–1898) was also an Army officer, and has been credited by historians with sparking the charge up [[Battle of San Juan Hill|San Juan Hill]] during the [[Spanish–American War]], at which Jules Ord was killed.Frank Everson Vandiver, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5Y6hC0s4URYC&pg=PA204 ''Black Jack: The Life and Times of John J. Pershing''], Volume 1, 1977, page 204G. J. A. O'Toole, [https://books.google.com/books?id=WozGjq1OAi0C&pg=PA318 ''The Spanish War: An American Epic – 1898''], 1986, page 318 Another uncle, James Thompson Ord (1863–1905), was a [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] in the Army, and his son, [[Lieutenant Colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] [[James Basevi Ord]] (1892–1938) was the cousin of James Garesche Ord.North & South Magazine, Incorporated, [https://books.google.com/books?id=l2MTAQAAMAAJ&q=%22james+thompson+ord%22+basevi&dq=%22james+thompson+ord%22+basevi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NO2eU8bRLdbMsQSE44C4AQ&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAQ ''North & South: The Magazine of Civil War Conflict''], Volume 8, 2005, page 393Bernarr Cresap, [https://books.google.com/books?id=P44sAAAAMAAJ&q=%22james+thompson+ord%22+cresap&dq=%22james+thompson+ord%22+cresap&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ke2eU8LOJNTJsQTHqYEI&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAw ''Appomattox Commander: The Story of General E.O.C. Ord''], 1981, page 399 ==Start of career== James Garesche Ord graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] in 1909 and received his commission as a [[Second lieutenant#United States|Second Lieutenant]] of [[Infantry Branch (United States)|Infantry]]. Initially assigned to the [[30th Infantry Regiment (United States)|30th Infantry Regiment]], his early postings included [[Fort Davis, Alaska|Fort Davis]] and [[Fort Gibbon]] in [[Alaska]], the [[Presidio of San Francisco]], and [[Old Stone Barracks|Plattsburg Barracks]] in [[New York (state)|New York]].George Washington Cullum, [https://books.google.com/books?id=kia5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA833&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+west+point+1909&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AoWYU5uUIa7isATa7oDoCA&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22james%20garesche%20ord%22%20west%20point%201909&f=false Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy], Volume 5, 1910, page 833California Digital Newspaper Collection, ''San Francisco Call'', [http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19130207.1.12# A General Court Martial is Appointed to Meet at Fort Gibbon, Alaska], February 7, 1913George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9Y-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1436&dq=%22james+Garesche+ord%22+edward+ord&hl=en&sa=X&ei=q36YU7uCCrKrsQTL34CYBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22james%20Garesche%20ord%22%20edward%20ord&f=false Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy], Volume 6, Part 2, 1920, page 1436 Ord served at [[Eagle Pass, Texas|Eagle Pass]] and [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], [[Texas]] during the [[Pancho Villa Expedition]], and was then assigned as Professor of Military Science at [[Culver Academies|Culver Military Academy]].George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9Y-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1436&dq=%22james+Garesche+ord%22+edward+ord&hl=en&sa=X&ei=q36YU7uCCrKrsQTL34CYBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22james%20Garesche%20ord%22%20edward%20ord&f=false Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy], Volume 6, Part 2, 1920, page 1436Edgar Z. Steever, James L. Frink, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eKJDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PR21&lpg=PR21&dq=%22james+g+ord%22+%22culver+military+academy%22&source=bl&ots=d8niAGQjXR&sig=7RvdittbXznk2S2ssfzGngTmak0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qYmYU5yHBtSqsQTUkIHADA&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22james%20g%20ord%22%20%22culver%20military%20academy%22&f=false The Cadet Manual], 1918, page xxi ==World War I== In 1917 Ord was assigned as [[aide-de-camp]] to [[Hunter Liggett]]. He served on the staff of the [[American Expeditionary Forces]] Headquarters and the [[41st Infantry Division (United States)|41st Division]], and was assigned as [[Provost Marshal]] for [[I Corps (United States)|I Corps]] before serving again as Liggett’s Aide at the end of the war and during the post-war occupation of [[Germany]].Georgetown University Library, Ord Family Papers, [https://repository.library.georgetown.edu/bitstream/handle/10822/559043/GTM.GAMMS267.html?sequence=1 Description, photo 79060, J. G. Ord, Aide de Camp, World War I, Germany], retrieved June 11, 2014George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9Y-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1436&dq=%22james+Garesche+ord%22+edward+ord&hl=en&sa=X&ei=q36YU7uCCrKrsQTL34CYBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22james%20Garesche%20ord%22%20edward%20ord&f=false Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy], Volume 6, Part 2, 1920, page 1436 ==Post-war== After the war Ord’s assignments included Assistant Plans, Operations and Training Officer (G3) for [[United States Army Central|Third Army]]. He graduated from the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College|Command and General Staff College]] in 1924 and remained as an instructor. He graduated from the [[United States Army War College|Army War College]] in 1929.Commandant, General Service Schools, Fort Leavenworth, [http://www.cgsc.edu/carl/download/reports/rep1927.pdf Annual Report], 1927, page 5 From 1930 to 1934 Ord served on the Supply and Logistics staff (G4) at the [[United States Department of War|War Department]], and he commanded the [[12th Infantry Regiment (United States)|12th Infantry Regiment]] from 1934 to 1936.George Washington Cullum, West Point Association of Graduates, [http://digital-library.usma.edu/libmedia/archives/cullum/VOL8_PART0002.PDF Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy], Volume 8, Part 2, 1940, pages 218-219George Washington Cullum, Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy, Volume 7, 1930, page 842 Ord was Director of the Infantry Board at [[Fort Benning]] from 1936 to 1938. (The Infantry Board was one of several panels the Army used to consider modernization of training, tactics, weapons and vehicles in the years before [[World War II]].)Cresap Society, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=BJWYU-DpGvSusATnn4HYBg&id=pytGAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+%22infantry+board%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22infantry+board%22 The History of the Cresaps], 1987, page 410 From 1938 to 1940 Ord commanded the [[57th Infantry Regiment (United States)|57th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Philippines]].Harrisburg Telegraph, [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/43162597/ Colonel Ord Due in July], May 2, 1940 ==World War II== In 1940 Ord was assigned as a Regular Army observer and advisor for the [[Pennsylvania Army National Guard|Pennsylvania National Guard]], responsible for taking steps to improve individual and collective readiness for the [[28th Infantry Division (United States)|28th Infantry Division]] during the train-up in advance of [[World War II]].Michael E. Weaver, [https://books.google.com/books?id=PrDsnbSjY_AC&pg=PA67&lpg=PA67&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+pennsylvania+instructor&source=bl&ots=odfLMFr3v4&sig=hrilRzhA4PD0luv87vyiHw86Gpo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bJaYU93WBoXfsATc-4KABQ&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22james%20garesche%20ord%22%20pennsylvania%20instructor&f=false Guard Wars: The 28th Infantry Division in World War II], 2010, page 67 From 1940 to 1942 he was Deputy Commander of the [[1st Infantry Division (United States)|1st Infantry Division]], receiving promotion to [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]]. From February to June, 1942 Ord commanded the 28th Infantry Division, capitalizing on the relationships he had developed while advising the [[Pennsylvania Army National Guard|Pennsylvania National Guard]] in 1940. Ord commanded the division until being succeeded by [[Omar Bradley]].George Catlett Marshall, author, Larry I. Bland, Sharon Ritenour Stevens, editors, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_1IfAQAAMAAJ&q=%22j+garesche+ord%22+%22assistant+division+commander%22&dq=%22j+garesche+ord%22+%22assistant+division+commander%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_peYU8CFBsXMsQTB2YLYDg&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA The Papers of George Catlett Marshall: July 1, 1939-December 6, 1941], 1986, page 635Pegge Parker, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GruT8eWeDSEC&pg=PA104&dq=%22james+g+ord%22+28th+division&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5qaYU5ecBuvQsQTTvIHwDQ&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22james%20g%20ord%22%2028th%20division&f=false 'teen Topics by Pegge Parker: The Greatest Generation Reflected in Vintage Advice Columns], 2008, pages 103-104Pottstown Mercury, [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/48954515/ Major Gen. Bradley Takes Command of 28th Division: Gen. Ord Transferred], July 1, 1942 Ord served as a member and later Chairman of the [[Brazil – United States relations#Second World War|Joint Brazil-US. Defense Commission]] from 1943 to 1945. The commission worked to strengthen military ties between the two countries during the war, reducing the likelihood of [[Axis powers]] attacks on US shipping as soldiers traveled across the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] to [[Africa]] and [[Europe]], and minimizing the influence of the Axis in [[South America]].Stetson Conn, Byron Fairchild, Office of the Chief of Military History, Department of the Army, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=dpiYU4XeFKXKsQSp7YKADQ&id=ocJHAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22j+garesche+ord%22+brazil+commission&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22j+garesche+ord%22 The Framework of Hemisphere Defense], 1960, page 319Dwight David Eisenhower, [https://books.google.com/books?id=nwKrAAAAIAAJ&q=%22james+g+ord%22+brazil+commission&dq=%22james+g+ord%22+brazil+commission&hl=en&sa=X&ei=R5mYU4H5M86osATvyYDwBQ&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA The Papers of Dwight David Eisenhower: The War Years], 1970, page 138 ==Awards== Ord’s Army awards and decorations included the [[Legion of Merit]]. His foreign awards included [[Ecuador]]'s [[Order of Abdon Calderón]], First Class, and Brazil’s [[Order of Military Merit (Brazil)|Order of Military Merit]] (Grand Officer) and War Medal.Association of Graduates, United States Military Academy, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=dqiYU-iXKenQsQSCo4HIDw&id=oT7cAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+%22lm%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22james+garesche+ord%22 Register of Graduates and Former Cadets of the United States Military Academy], 1975, page 316George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mcHeAAAAMAAJ&q=%22james+garesche+ord%22+ecuador&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+ecuador&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FaqYU6S6EYS_sQS0_4K4CQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy], Volume 9, 1950, page 133 ==Retirement, death and burial== Ord retired in 1946 and resided in [[Washington, D.C.]] until his death from a heart attack at [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]] on April 17, 1960. He was buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]], Section 2, Site 979 LH.Potomac Corral of the Westerners, [https://books.google.com/books?id=oXEvAQAAMAAJ&q=%22james+g+ord%22+%22walter+reed%22&dq=%22james+g+ord%22+%22walter+reed%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h6yYU4_YI8GlsASm0IDQCg&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAQ Corral Dust: Death Notice, James G. Ord], Volume 10, 1960, unknown page numberArlington National Cemetery, [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/GravesiteLocator/GravesiteLocator.aspx Gravesite Locator], retrieved June 11, 2014 ==Family== In April 1927 Ord married Irene Helen Walsh of [[Memphis, Tennessee]] (1900-1993). They were the parents of three children: James G. Ord, Jr. (1928-1994); Marian E. Ord (born 1930); and Edward O. C. Ord (born 1936).Army and Navy Journal, Incorporated, [https://books.google.com/books?id=WfkYAQAAMAAJ&q=%22james+garesche+ord%22+irene+walsh&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+irene+walsh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Tq2YU7yCLIzjsATWgIHQDg&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAg Army, Navy, and Air Force Journal], Volume 97, Issues 27-52, 1960, page 961John McGill, [https://books.google.com/books?id=c2Y2AAAAMAAJ&q=%22james+garesche+ord%22+irene+walsh&dq=%22james+garesche+ord%22+irene+walsh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Tq2YU7yCLIzjsATWgIHQDg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAQ The Beverley family of Virginia: descendants of Major Robert Beverley, 1641-1687, and allied families], 1956, page 692 Irene Walsh Ord was a graduate of [[University of Memphis|West Tennessee College]] and the [[University of Tennessee College of Law|University of Tennessee Law School]], and practiced law before her marriage to Ord. In 1979 she married Brigadier General (Retired) Philip S. Gage (1885-1982), one of Ord’s West Point classmates.Arlington Cemetery.Net, [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jamesgar.htm Obituary, Irene W. Gage], retrieved June 11, 2014 ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jamesgar.htm James Garesche Ord] at [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net ArlingtonCemetery.Net] * {{Findagrave|41558421}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ord, James Garesche}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1960 deaths]] [[Category:People from Durango, Colorado]] [[Category:People from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:United States Army generals]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:United States Army Command and General Staff College alumni]] [[Category:United States Army War College alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Abdon Calderón]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Military Merit (Brazil)]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]]
